MSE Policy: Supersedes the following documents at Southend Hospital: IC007 Policies for Prevention and Management of Meticillin Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA); Basildon Hospital: CP/PO/00019 Infection Control Policy for Management and Control of MRSA; Broomfield Hospital: 04075 Prevention and management of methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

data.text: Contents
Key Elements of Policy / Guideline (author to section accordingly) .............................. 7
Introduction

Staphylococcus aureus is a common bacterium that lives harmlessly on the skin and nose of about a third of the population. However it is the commonest cause of skin and soft tissue infection acquired in the community, or in the hospital following surgery or other procedures that cause a break in the skin. It has the potential to cause a range of invasive disease including post-operative wound infection; bone and joint infections; endocarditis; urinary tract infection; septicaemia and bacteraemia.

Meticillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a form of Staphylococcus aureus that has become resistant to antibiotics commonly used to treat Staphylococcus aureus. Meticillin resistance indicates flucloxacillin resistance and resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, (penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems). MRSA resistance was first reported in 1961 and MRSA continues to be endemic in many UK hospitals. Specific measures have been shown to be effective in preventing and controlling MRSA, necessary because MRSA can cause serious illness which is harder to treat due to limited therapeutic options and results in additional healthcare costs e.g. as a result of increased length of hospital stay and cost of antibiotics to treat the infection. The emergence of Vancomycin resistant S. aureus (VRSA) is further cause for concern.

Although in most circumstances MRSA lives harmlessly on the skin or in the nose, vulnerable patients are at risk of developing an MRSA infection. The majority of patients who acquire MRSA are merely colonised, not ill and do not require antibiotic therapy. A proportion, possibly up to one third, depending on patient population, develops infection which may become invasive and in some cases contribute to, or result in death.

Like other Staphylococci, MRSA strains can pass from one person to another by direct or indirect contact (e.g. via hands, equipment etc.). Identification, treatment and management of individuals carrying MRSA using interventions such as screening, MRSA suppression/decolonisation regimes, patient isolation and giving appropriate antimicrobial prophylactic regimes can reduce the risk of MRSA infection, including MRSA bloodstream infection, and MRSA transmission between patients.

Patients and the public are increasingly aware of MRSA and regard it as an indicator of the quality of patient care. They require re-assurance that all healthcare professionals are taking reasonable precautions to minimise spread and it is their professional responsibility to do so.

This policy provides details on the standards required for the detection and management of MRSA AT Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust (MSE) in order to protect adult, paediatric and neonatal patients from infection or colonisation with MRSA, prevent the transmission of MRSA and to safely manage and treat patients who are colonised with MRSA.
Scope
The objectives of this policy are:
To prevent the transmission of MRSA across the MSE
To protect patients from infection or colonisation with MRSA
To ensure patients who are confirmed to have MRSA are managed safely and appropriately, and receive adequate information about their condition
Definitions

table_items.text: The presence of MRSA on mucosal and skin surfaces, without the presence of clinical manifestations of illness or infection
Elimination of MRSA carrier state through the use of topical anti- bacterial applications
Director of Infection Prevention and Control

A patient admitted following a planned period of waiting. This may be from a waiting list, from being “booked” (i.e. given a date at the time the decision to admit was made) or following any other plan for delayed admission
Patients admitted directly i.e. in the absence of any planned waiting period
The microbiology laboratory reporting database system
The presence of MRSA in a body site, where there is clinical evidence of infection
MRSA is present, typically in areas of either skin or mucosal carriage but occasionally may be positive from a sterile clinical sample (e.g. blood cultures) alone.
The process of obtaining microbiological swabs to identify the presence of MRSA in order to suppress the bacteria by prescribed treatment

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Infection Prevention and Control Committees (IPCC) are responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control legislation or guidance

The Managing Director has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors
Chief Operating Officer/Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Director of Nursing holds delegated Executive responsibility for the management control of healthcare associated infection
The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) will have operational responsibly for the effective implementation of this policy

Consultant Microbiologist/Infection Control Doctor. To work with the Director of Infection Prevention and Control to deliver the Trust's annual infection control agenda. Clinical lead for overseeing, providing advice on and implementation of infection control practices across the Trust.

On-call Managers and the On–call Executive are responsible for providing senior and executive leadership to ensure implementation of this policy, and for ensuring infection risks are fully considered and documented when complex decisions need to me made regarding capacity and patient flow.

Consultant medical and surgical  staff are responsible for ensuring that all possible measures are taken to reduce the spread of infection to patients, visitors and staff. They are responsible for ensuring this policy is implemented in their areas and for ensuring all staff who work within their areas adhere to the principles and standards at all times. They are responsible for ensuring their junior staff read and understand this policy and adhere to the principles contained in it all times.

Head of Nursing for Infection Prevention and Control (MSE) - will give advice against this policy and ensure that all staff have access to this policy via the Trust Intranet and ensure that it is updated every two years or in line with current national guidance.

The Infection Prevention and Control Teams (IPCT's) are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and advising ward staff on control measures, providing them with the necessary advice

Site Management Team to facilitate the appropriate placement of patients with potential or known infections into appropriate isolation rooms as soon as possible and to escalate difficulties in isolation to the Infection Prevention Team.

Matrons and Ward/Department Managers – have the responsibility to be conversant with this policy and ensure that all staff understands the requirements of this policy and their responsibility to comply with it.
All Staff must comply with this policy, liaising with the IPCT in a timely manner if in need of advice or support.
Key Elements of Policy / Guideline
Screening method
5.1.1  Screens to be obtained are:-
Nose - one swab to be used for both anterior nares
Groin - one to be used to swab both groins
Any skin lesions or wounds
Urinary catheter specimen (CSU) if applicable
PEG site if present
Sputum if expectorating
MRSA Screening technique
5.2.1 Nose: Always dip the swab in the sterile gel solution in the bottom of the containing tube, when swabbing adopt the ‘tear drop' technique, up one side, twist and swab down the other side.
5.2.2 Swabs must be labelled with the patient details and sent to the laboratory with a completed ICE/ request form. The investigation required is “MRSA screen”.

5.2.3 NB: when a MRSA screen is requested, MRSA is the only organism that the will be examined for. If a full microscopy, culture and sensitivity, (MC&S) is also required, this must be specifically requested.
Elective admissions
5.3.1 The purpose of pre-operative screening is to minimise the risk of the patient becoming infected with his or her own MRSA and to minimise the risk of transmission to vulnerable patients
5.3.2 The revised DoH Guidance (2014) recommended that the previous practice of mandatory MRSA screening of all elective admissions to NHS hospitals was to be streamlined.
5.3.3 The current DoH exclusions still remain:
Day Case Ophthalmology
Day Case Dental
Day Case Endoscopy (including cystoscopy, colonoscopy, bronchoscopy and gastroscopy)
Minor dermatology procedures i.e. treatment of warts and liquid nitrogen applications
Children/paediatrics not in a high risk group
Maternity/obstetric patients except planned Caesarean and high risk cases, i.e. high risk of complications in the mother and/or potential complications in the baby
Day case infusions e.g. blood transfusions, methylprednisolone
Termination of Pregnancy patients unless there are risk factors that indicate otherwise
Screening of elective/planned admissions
5.4.1 Patients identified as requiring MRSA screening must have swabs undertaken at the outpatient appointment when the decision is made to electively admit the patient
5.4.2 At pre-assessment the nurses will check (that if required) the screen has been taken and screen as required

5.4.3 Elective admission screening should be completed as close to the admission date as possible. Whilst it is recognised that this will not always be achievable within a specific timeframe, the maximum time frame from screening to admission is: 18 weeks
5.4.4 If previously obtained MRSA screen exceeds the set criteria, patients will be followed up by the pre assessment nurses
5.4.5 All patients regardless of swab result will be provided with antibacterial wash with instructions to commence use 48 hours prior to the procedure
5.4.6 Patients undergoing screening will be issued with an information leaflet explaining the reasons and the procedure
Process for taking action on elective/planned patient screening results

5.5.1 The IPCT will inform the Pre Assessment Nurses if a patient is found to be MRSA positive. It will be the responsibly of the pre assessment nurse to inform the patient, carer ,GP or care home of the positive results arrange decolonisation treatment and follow up screening
5.5.2 All patients found to be MRSA positive will have an alert placed on the Medway/Lorenzo System by the IPCT's
Emergency admissions/transfers form other NHS Trusts
5.6.1 All  emergency  admissions  must  be  screened  on  admission  (excluding  children unless in they are previously known MRSA or repatriated from another hospital)

5.6.2 Patients admitted to medical and surgical assessments units must have a nose and groin screen for MRSA when the decision to admit the patient has been made. If unable to screen prior to being transferred to the ward this must be included in the hand over to the admitting ward
5.6.3 The staff on the receiving ward must check that a MRSA screen has been obtained. If a screen has not been obtained the patient must be screened on admission to the ward

5.6.4 Patients admitted directly to the ward, such as direct from an OPD clinic etc., must be screened on admission to the ward. If a patient's positive result is not known until after discharge, an information letter will be sent to the patient and their GP and Care Home if appropriate
Screening for renal dialysis patients

5.7.1 All patients new to the renal dialysis programme will be screened for MRSA. This will take place before formation of vascular access wherever possible. Renal patients requiring dialysis out of area will be screened prior to transfer.
5.7.2 Patients should be re-screened before and after holiday (whether locally or abroad) and after discharge from the hospital.

5.7.3 Known colonised MRSA positive patients should be re-screened monthly and dialysed in the side room under barrier nursing precautions. Decolonisation treatment should be prescribed and the patient monitored to ensure compliance.
Chemotherapy
5.8.1  Adult chemotherapy patients attending for treatment should be screened at the beginning of their chemotherapy programme.
Maternity Screening

5.9.1 Currently all pregnant healthcare workers and high risk obstetric cases that attend Southend University Hospital for antenatal care or are being managed by the trust community midwives will receive a nose and groin screen for MRSA at approximately  weeks gestation (see Appendix 1 for further guidance)
5.9.2 Repeat screening of inpatients
Any patient in hospital for longer than 28 days should be re-screened (ensure that antibacterial body washes are stopped 48 hours prior to screen being obtained)
All inter-ward transfers (excluding assessment wards) should be re-screened
Screening of contacts (i.e. other patients)

5.10.1 Screening of patient contacts of a newly identified MRSA positive patient may be undertaken if advised by the IPCT. Also screening may be also required where a cluster of cases is detected or in the event of an outbreak of staphylococcal sepsis.
5.10.2 The decision to screen other patient contacts is influenced by the risk group of the affected unit and/or the number of newly affected MRSA positive patients.
Screening of the environment or equipment
5.11.1  Environmental screening is undertaken only on the instruction of the Infection Prevention and Control Team.
MRSA risk reduction for patients not known to be MRSA positive.

5.12.1 At Southend Hospital and Broomfield Hospital - to reduce the risk of MRSA colonisation and infection, all adult patients not known to be MRSA positive, will be offered antibacterial body wash to use on admission and during their stay.
5.12.2 At Basildon Hospital anti-bacterial body washes are only provided to patients with CVC in situ
Treatment of MRSA colonisation/infection

5.13.1  Patients who are immunocompromised, have invasive devices in situ or undergo invasive procedures are at greater risk of developing clinical infection following acquisition of MRSA putting other vulnerable patients at risk of acquiring the organism. Treatment will consist of topical decolonisation and, in the case of clinical infection, appropriate intravenous antibiotics.
Standard decolonisation treatment

5.14.1 Anti-bacterial body wash to be used once daily for five days. Using a disposable washcloth, the skin should be moistened and the solution applied undiluted all over the body and left for 1 minute contact time before rinsing off thoroughly. Specialist dermatology advice must be sought for patients with skin disorders

5.14.2 2% Mupirocin (Bactroban) nasal ointment to be applied to the anterior nares twice a day for five days. Gently pinch the sides of the nose together after application to ensure an even distribution of the ointment
5.14.3 As with any topical treatment there is a risk of skin irritation. If this occurs, stop treatment and contact the IPCT
Decolonisation treatment for neonates and young children

5.15.1 All paediatric patients found to be MRSA positive should receive topical decolonisation as an attempt to eradicate MRSA, and reduce the subsequent risk of infection, unless there are contra-indications or clinical reasons why this is not appropriate. In these circumstances the reason for not decolonising the patient must be documented.
5.15.2 Mupirocin ointment 2% (Bactroban) BD for 5 days and Octensian /anti-bacterial body wash once a day for 5 days
Treatment of Mupirocin-resistant strains
5.16.1 Naseptin (chlorhexidine 0.1% with neomycin 0.5%) nasal ointment is the recommended alternative to Bactroban.
5.16.2 Naseptin is a prescription-only medicine licensed for the eradication of nasal infection with, and carriage of, staphylococci
5.16.3 Naseptin is applied four times daily for 10 days to eliminate organisms from the nostrils
5.16.4 Naseptin is contra-indicated in patients who have allergy to peanuts, soya or chlorhexidine. Please contact the Microbiologist /IPCT to discuss alternatives to Naseptin if contra-indicated
Follow up screening and treatment of inpatients

5.17.1 After completion of the five day decolonisation treatment, two days of normal washing must take place before a repeat nose and groin screen is obtained on day eight. The anti-bacterial body washes must then be recommenced and continued until patient discharge.

5.17.2 Weekly nose and groin screens are to be obtained following two days without treatment (see Appendix 2). Repeated courses of nasal Mupirocin are not recommended due to the risk of developing antibiotic resistance
Treatment of MRSA infection
5.18.1  If MRSA infection is suspected, advice on treatment must be sought from the microbiologist.
Prophylaxis for invasive procedures/surgery
5.19.1 Prophylaxis is indicated for the following:
Patients who are known to be colonised with MRSA at any time in the last 12 months; or

Considered to be very high risk for carriage, e.g. long term nursing/residential home care, chronic wound skin condition, transferred from another hospital or previous inpatient at any hospital in the last 12months; or
In an emergency situation, where MRSA status or the risk factors are unknown
5.19.2 Please refer to individual trust recommendations with regards to MRSA prophylaxis for details of appropriate drugs, dosages and timings.
5.19.3 Southend Hospital: MMG020 General Empiric Antibiotic Guidelines for Adults MMG065 General Empiric Antibiotic Guidelines for Paediatrics
5.19.4 Basildon hospital: CP/GU/00457 Adult antibiotic guidelines; CP/PO/0019 Paediatric antibiotic guidelines MMG042 Adult Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Orthopaedics and General Surgery
5.19.5 Mid Essex Hospital: Mid Essex Hospital Online MicroGuide – Adult antimicrobial Guide and Paediatric Antimicrobial Guide
Re-admission of patients previously found to be MRSA positive
5.20.1 On re-admission, previously known MRSA patients must be screened as described in section 5.1.The patient should be considered MRSA positive until the results of the screen are known.
5.20.2 Strict adherence to standard infection control precautions is essential in reducing the risk of transmission of MRSA to other patients and vulnerable body sites on the same patient.
Standard precautions include:
Hand hygiene before and after each patient contact and in between procedures on the same patient

Disposable apron and gloves are to be worn when contact with blood or body fluids and/or mucous membranes is anticipated. Aprons to be worn to protect clothing during bed making and direct patient care
Strict aseptic technique for invasive procedures
Patient management
Isolation precautions

6.1.1 Patients found to be, or previously known to be, colonised or infected with MRSA should be nursed in a single room with en-suite facilities wherever possible. If a single room is unavailable refer to the Isolation Policy. The Nurse in Charge to risk assess the need for isolation and document this in the medical notes ‘need for isolation'
6.1.2 The single room door should always be closed during procedures that may generate staphylococcal dispersal, e.g. bed making, dressing wounds, chest physiotherapy.
6.1.3 A laminated ‘standard precautions' isolation sign must be clearly displayed on the outside of the isolation room door .All wards across the MSE have a supply of these.

6.1.4 Disposable gloves and disposable aprons are required for direct patient care. They must be removed prior to leaving the isolation room/patient bed space and hands decontaminated immediately after glove removal. It is unnecessary to wear gloves and apron for activities that do not involve significant patient or environmental contact, for example, when administering oral medication, providing meals, or conversing with the patient. Visitors are, therefore, not required to wear protective clothing

6.1.5 Wherever possible, the patient must have their own dedicated equipment. Where this is not possible, it must be appropriately decontaminated before use with the next patient using Clinell Universal Wipes. Contact the IPCT for advice

6.1.6 Patients identified as MRSA positive who are on ICP (Integrated Care Pathway for the Last Days of Life) should continue with the anti-bacterial body wash as part of the daily hygiene routine. This will help to minimise transmission of infection
6.1.7 Bed linen and patient clothing are to be changed daily. Used linen must be handled carefully to reduce the dispersal of skin squames and disposed of immediately into a white plastic linen bag
6.1.8 It is essential that all unnecessary equipment and clutter is removed from the isolation room/patient bed space to enable effective cleaning
Actions to be taken by the infection prevention and control team when a patient is identified as having MRSA

6.2.1 The microbiology results are visible to the Infection Prevention and Control Team by the laboratory throughout the day. The IPCT will inform the ward when notified and provide support, advice and monitoring.
6.2.2 The IPCT establishes any previous MRSA history using the Electronic Patient Record System (Medway/Lorenzo). The information is documented in the MRSA profile document (IPCTs records).
6.2.3 The IPCT will undertake a brief summary of the patient's immediate previous movements and document these in the IPNS records.

6.2.4 The IPCT add an Infection Control Alert to Medway/Lorenzo. These alerts notify all clerical staff and clinical staff who have access to the system that for future admissions they must accommodate the patient in a side room and obtain a full screen
6.2.5 The patient details are added on to the IPCT database

6.2.6 The  IPCT  will  ensure  MRSA  Decolonisation  Regime  has  been  prescribed  and commenced. The MRSA care pathway/decolonisation regime is in placed and is completed daily. Broomfield electronic via shared drive
6.2.7 At Southend ward have a stock , via ICT OR staff net Infection Control page to print out and place in the patients bed side notes Basildon via the shared drive to print off
6.2.8 Any action and advice regarding management and decolonisation given by the IPCT should be documented in the patient's notes

6.2.9 To facilitate their safe and effective management, all patients found to be colonised or infected a yellow MRSA information sheet (see appendix 3) is to be placed in the patients' medical record

6.2.10 All patients found to be colonised or infected with MRSA at Southend hospital will have an Alert sticker placed on to their medical notes by the IPCN. This will allow staff to identify these patients on subsequent admissions
Communication and Patent /Carer Information

6.3.1 Patients, carers and visitors must be provided with accurate information on MRSA. This is the responsibility of the medical and nursing team admitting or providing care for the patient, and includes giving the patient, or their relatives a copy of the relevant Trust information leaflet

6.3.2 Relatives/carers/visitors must be advised of the precautions required when visiting a patient  with  MRSA,  e.g.  hand  hygiene  and  wearing  of  personal  protective equipment if contributing to patient care
Action to take if a patient refuses MRSA screening, decolonisation or risk reduction measures
6.4.1 A clear explanation must be provide to the patient explaining the rationale for the screening/ decolonisation/risk reduction measures
6.4.2 The potential risk of not undertaking these measures must be explained to the patient  so  that  the  patient  understands  the  potential  consequences  of  not undertaking these actions
6.4.3 The  patients  refusal  and  discussions  related  to  the  above  must  be  clearly documented in the medical notes
Alert removal
6.5.1 Patients should continue to be treated as MRSA until confirmation from the Infection Prevention and Control Team that the patient has been cleared and the MRSA alert removed.

6.5.2 The  criteria  to  have  the  Medway/Lorenzo  Infection  Risk  Alert  removed  is  risk assessed by a member if the IPCT on an individual patient basis, a patient may be deemed as to no longer have MRSA carriage if:

The patient has screened negative for a minimum period of 12 months and has a negative admission screen. , The ICN will take into consideration that there are no other high risks for MRSA carriage (nursing/residential care/exfoliating. skin disease/any catheters in situ, including intravenous devices and PEGs)
Clearance is unlikely in patients with risk factors for long term carriage e.g. chronic wounds, permanent tracheostomy, long term indwelling devices and skin shedders
The Alert will be removed on Medway/Lorenzo when the patient is discharge- This action can only be taken by a member of the Infection Prevention & Control Team.
Contraindications for isolating patients
6.6.1 When a patient's condition dictates that close observation is necessary and this cannot be achieved in a side room.
6.6.2 If  the  isolation  room  lacks  equipment  required  for  the  patient  e.g.  specialised monitoring.
6.6.3 If the patient is restless, confused, wandering and isolation might be a hazard.
6.6.4 Where a patient fears isolation, i.e. being away from the sight of others with the door closed.
6.6.5 The door can be left open, following risk assessment. Document this in the patient's clinical record. The IPCT may use the sticker below
Cohort Nursing

6.7.1  Where there are a number of patients colonised with MRSA on the same ward, it is advisable to nurse all the patients in the same bay area, i.e. a cohort. Advice on cohort nursing can be found in the Trust Isolation policy.
Patient information

6.8.1  It is vital that patients and their carers' are provided with accurate information about MRSA and its management. The IPCN's are available to speak to patients, their carers' and relatives during office hours, but, this is also the responsibility of the medical and nursing team providing care for the patient. An information leaflet is available and must be offered to the patient and/or relatives.
Environmental cleaning

6.9.1  The room or bed space occupied by the patient with MRSA should be thoroughly cleaned daily with emphasis on areas that accumulate dust, including high surfaces. Following discharge of the patient, the room must be terminally cleaned using Diff X solution
Clinical investigations

6.10.1 Patients colonised or infected with MRSA can undergo investigations in all departments providing the department has been informed in advance. Staff within the department must practise standard infection control precautions and all equipment used must be decontaminated before re-use. Surfaces are to be cleaned /decontaminated using Clinell Universal Wipes before the next patient is seen. Commodes must be decontaminated using a sporicidal product .The patient does not require to be placed to the end of any scheduled lists.

6.10.2 Please note short term exposure to other patients in clinics or departments is not generally a problem unless the MRSA patient has exposed cutaneous sites of carriage and/or a skin disease such as eczema/psoriasis. In these situations the clinic or department should arrange for the patient to be seen straight away on entry to avoid prolonged contact with other patients.
Operating Theatres
6.11.1 Theatres must be informed of a patient's MRSA status in advance.
6.11.2 MRSA positive patients can be placed anywhere on the operating theatre provided all surfaces and equipment cleaned between the MRSA posit patient and the next patient on the list

6.11.3 Theatre surfaces in close contact or near the patient, such as the operating table or instrument trolley, should be decontaminated with Diff X solution (1 sachet to 1 litre of warm water) before being used for the next patient.
6.11.4 Patients should be segregated as far as possible within the recovery area and nursed by staff dedicated to their care
Mobilisation
6.12.1  Patients colonised or infected with MRSA can leave the isolation room to allow mobilisation along hospital corridors, preferably following daily decolonisation treatment.
Transfers to other wards

6.13.1  If clinical need dictates, patients colonised or infected with MRSA can be transferred from one ward to another. The receiving area must be informed in advance to ensure that appropriate facilities are available and the necessary precautions are applied.
Transporting patients within the hospital

6.14.1  Gloves and aprons are not required for pushing a wheelchair/ trolley/bed or for brief social contact when guiding a patient onto a chair or trolley. However, it is essential that hands be decontaminated with alcohol hand sanitiser after such contact. Gloves and aprons are to be worn for significant bodily contact with patients when moving them into position onto a bed or trolley, but must be removed once this task has been completed and hands must then be washed and the wheelchair/bed/trolley cleaned using Clinell Universal wipes.
Patient discharge or transfer

6.15.1  Whilst treatment of MRSA infection may result in a prolonged hospital stay, the discharge of patients found to be colonised with MRSA should not be delayed. MRSA is not a reason for patients to be refused admission to nursing or residential homes. Staff must ensure that the GP/care placement/ community nursing service are informed of the patient's MRSA status. In order to facilitate safe care, accurate information on MRSA status must be recorded. Accurate information on MRSA status including information on topical decolonisation and specimen results, must be recorded and communicated to staff in primary and community care upon transfer to another organisation or discharge home. This can be communicated by using the Trust discharge letter and “inter health organisation transfer form”
Last Offices

6.16.1  The same precautions used in life to care for patients i.e. gloves, aprons and hand hygiene, should be used in death. A body bag is not required for patients who have died while colonised or infected with MRSA. If there is a risk of leakage of body fluids a body bag should be used and area of leakage sealed to protect further handlers.
Routine Staff Screening for MRSA
6.17.1 Where there are concerns about MRSA colonisation or infection with regard to staff members, these will be handled by the Occupational Health Department, in strict confidence.

6.17.2 Screening of staff is not currently undertaken as a matter of routine, in line with national  guidance,  although,  following  advice  from  a  consultant  microbiologist, groups of staff may be required to be screened, based on clinical evidence and risk. This confidential screening is undertaken through occupational health.
Surveillance

6.18.1 The IPCT will routinely undertake surveillance for new MRSA isolates. The team will inform clinical areas of all newly identified MRSA colonised/infected patients and advise on treatment and isolation precautions.
6.18.2 In the event of a suspected outbreak of MRSA, refer to the MSE Infection Control Outbreak Policy
Training requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control up dates. The  IPCT  has  primary  responsibility  for  providing  training  on  the  policy  where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Compliance against and knowledge of Policy
Infection Prevention and Control Site Lead Nurses
Infection Prevention and Control Committee Divisional Governance
Infection Prevention and Control Committee Divisional Governance

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve Infection Prevention and Control Policies. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals
(Refer to appendix 3)
References
Guidance on the reporting and monitoring arrangement and post infection review process for MRSA bloodstream infections from April 2014 (version 2).
https://www.england.nhs.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/mrsa-pir-guid-april14.pdf

Implementation of modified admission MRSA admission screening guidance for NHS   https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/3451 44/Implementation_of_modified_admission_MRSA_screening_guidance_for_NHS.p df

Guidelines for the control and prevention of Meticillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in healthcare facilities. Journal of Hospital Infection, Volume 63, Supplement 1, May 2006, Pages S1-S44 . J.E. Coia, G.J. Duckworth, D.I. Edwards, M. Farrington, C. Fry, H. Humphreys, C. Mallaghan, D.R. Tucker and for the Joint Working Party of the British Society of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy, the Hospital Infection Society, and the Infection Control Nurses Association

Appendix 2: Alert Sheet

table_items.text: This patient is known to be, or has been previously colonised with MRSA, Please
ensure you follow Trust Procedures and Policies to protect our patients
MRSA Policy MSEPO-20255. Pathway and Precautions to be followed e.g. trust procedures and Invasive Device Tools (blood cultures require senior authorisation)

Refer to Infection Prevention & Control Team if admitted (Monday – Friday 8.00 –17.00) for patients admitted out of hours, Infection prevention and Control Nurse will visit patient next working day. Continue to follow MSEPO-20255.
Swabs to be obtained and send for screening
Antibiotics required? – Refer to MRSA Guidance or consult with Microbiologist
For further information please contact the Infection Prevention and Control Department

data.text: Policy for the prevention and management of Meticillin Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) / MSEPO-20255/1.2

Policy for the prevention and management of Meticillin Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) / MSEPO-20255/1.2
Appendix 3: Preliminary equality analysis
This assessment relates to: Policy for the prevention and management of Meticillin Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) (please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
To make three separate policies into one.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To ensure a consistent approach across the MSE
Who benefits from this change and how?
Everyone, as this is a uniform approach
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Head of Infection Prevention and Control
